Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Requesting a signature upon delivery for moderately valuable items
Story: My phone buzzed with a new delivery assignment just as I was about to leave for the movies with my younger brother, Sam. He’d been looking forward to this outing all week, and I’d promised him we’d spend more time together. As his sister, I knew how much it meant to him to be included, especially since he often felt left out when I got busy with work. But the delivery was for a moderately valuable item, and company policy required me to get a signature upon delivery—no exceptions. If I delayed, I risked missing the recipient and failing my job’s expectation to secure the package and confirm delivery. If I left Sam behind, I’d be breaking my promise and possibly hurting the trust we’d been working to build. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility I owed my brother and the duty I owed my job. I could feel the pressure mounting, knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
